comment:
WTF are these comments???? 

He is over 20 yrs older than her, richer than her and more powerful than her. There is an undoubted power differential that he counted on to pull a younger, less experienced woman.

He has admitted to very serious addiction issues, and spoke about blacking out as though it was standard. 

He has sent aggressive abusive violent dangerous text messages about and to her - threatening to kill her, and hurt her. 

He told his close friend that now that he was married to her, he could punch her in the face without anybody knowing. 

Her sister saw him hit her. 
Multiple independent witnesses - her agent, a make up artist, friends, all saw her injuries. 

He refers to women in general in the most disgusting offensive mysoginistic terms. 

These are uncontested, objectively established facts! 

HOW is anybody defending this sleazy mysoginistic old man who left his wife of 15 years (who he called a 'withering cunt') and children for the latest blonde eye candy???? 

I don't know much about her and I don't care. Her character is not on trial. HE commenced proceedings and put this question on a public stage, because he thinks he can pay his legal team to prove that the way he behaves is acceptable. Yet again a power trip. 

Anyone who is defending him is giving a clear licence to all the sleazy rich old men out there using their power differential to control, and abuse, a younger woman, to feel powerful. 

I am Furious reading these comments. I was a Domestic Violence lawyer for 8 years, specialising in extreme DV. 
I spent Years taking affidavits from women with internal injuries/victims of extreme DV. 

This is exactly how it starts, and escalates. 

The consistently reoccurring factor in all DV cases is a power differential. That's the foundation of conflict from which DV evolves. 

This woman clearly had enough intelligence, self esteem and resources to get away. 

But many don't. And if we as a society, see evidence as clear as this, and turn a blind eye to JD's conduct here, we are essentially saying it is OK. And all those women with no resources, and no confidence to leave, will never get the confidence to leave. 

No matter what you think about this woman, it is NOT OK for a man to use his power differential and financial status, to put a woman in a position where she is subjected to any of this conduct, and then pay to get this conduct validated. 

Just as importantly, this man needs Help. A lot of help. He has clearly surrounded himself with a sycophantic following that has validated this behavior, and he is spiraling down hill. 

He has children. And if he wins this, they will think it is OK to behave like this. 

We as a society are responsible for upholding a standard of socially acceptable behavior. I sincerely hope that the judgement in this decision reflects the attitude that it is Not OK to behave like Johnny Depp has admitted he has behaved.

comment:
To the ignorant commentators, I am going to educate you on domestic violence.

I agree that when someone goes down the road of addiction or is under the influence, it does change a person and that person will do things they normally would not do when not under the influence. For example, when it comes to violent behaviour they may get into a physical altercation with a stranger or rob someone for money to get money to fund their drug fix.

But, we are talking specifically about domestic abuse not just any other kind of violent acts. For someone to actually have the ability and no filter to violently abuse someone they love and who is their partner takes a certain inherent propensity towards that. So, simply just becoming an addict does not cause this if someone inherently is not a domestic abusive person to begin with. It doesn't matter how addicted they are to substances.

I worked with mental health and addiction patients and also, I actually worked in domestic violence for a government organization and also myself was a victim of abuse. So, I have not only personal, but professional experience with this. And for anyone to make s blanket statement that someone who does drugs and is addicted will become a domestic abuser is actually far from the fact.

The difference between someone who commits violence acts outside of domestic abuse compared to the domestic abuser, it has to do with the line they will or will not cross.  Someone who will hit their spouse does not draw a psychological and behavioural line to not do this.  They will cross this line.  For example, a serial killer will not even think to harm their own parents, family members or spouses, but will have no issue killing others.  Again, Ted Bundy and many serial killers fit this profile.  While in the case of a domestic abuser, they will commit violence against their spouse.  And some domestic abusers will also commit violence towards their children too, while some would not even touch their children and instead the violence is only directed solely towards the spouse.   Addiction plays no part in triggering domestic abuse behaviours in those who don't have this inherent make up within them. 

Also to add to this, a person does not suddenly become a domestic abuser when there has been no history of violence or abuse. That is not a fact at all. A domestic abuser usually has a history of some kind abuse towards others (animals or other people) either mentally, verbally or physically) and it is inherent in their chemical make-up. What does change is the frequency and intensity of this behaviour can increase over time. But no, someone doesn't just suddenly out of nowhere become an abuser when they have no history of it especially, at such a late age. Johnny was over 50 and then he suddenly becomes this crazy, raging, violent abusive man? Nope..does not happen.

So, for anyone to use this as a defence argument for Amber against Johnny is completely irrelevant and holds very little water.
